doc.after: Mongolian and other scholars have suggested that the Xiongnu spoke a Mongolic language.[2][62][63] Mongolian archaeologists proposed that the Slab Grave Culture people were the ancestors of the Xiongnu, and some scholars have suggested that the Xiongnu may have been the ancestors of the Mongols.[64] According to "Book of Song", (section Joujan), "Joujan's (Rouran Khaganate) another name was "Tatar" or "Tartar" and they were Xiongnu's tribe". Nikita Bichurin considered Xiongnu and Xianbei to be two subgroups (or dynasty) of one ethnicity.[65] Genghis Khan refers to the time of Modu Chanyu as "the remote times of our Chanyu" in his letter to Daoist Qiu Chuji".[66]
